nodes.text: Machine learning algorithms can be used to predict stock market movements and assist investors in making buy/sell decisions
This paper conducts a systematic literature review (SLR) to summarize machine learning methods, input attributes, and evidence for stock market prediction
Combining event information or news with machine learning models (especially neural networks) improves stock prediction accuracy

Different input attributes influence prediction and commonly used inputs include market history, news/events, public mood (social media), commodity and oil rates, interest rate, foreign exchange, and macroeconomic indicators

Multiple supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms have been applied to stock prediction including linear regression, neural networks, genetic algorithms, support vector machines, k-nearest neighbor, and random forest
SLR search process: initial retrieval of 550 papers from digital libraries (Elsevier, ACM, IEEE, Google Scholar), screening by title, then abstract, then full text, resulting in 45 included papers
Inclusion criteria required papers to be in English, fully available, and relevant to stock market prediction; quality assessment considered author contributions

Evidence from multiple studies (Fung et al., Kohara et al., Mittermayer, Hong & Han) shows event/news features combined with neural nets or text mining yield improved forecasting performance (reported increase example: ~5% accuracy gain when adding event knowledge)

Evidence: studies report specific attribute effects â€” fuel price changes strongly affect market performance; network indicators are important during crises; macro factors (consumer spending, investment, unemployment, inflation, federal funds rate) influence trends
Evidence: Support Vector Machine (SVM) frequently used and reported as superior to some classifiers in several studies (Huang et al., Shen et al., Lin et al., Das & Padhy)

Evidence: Random Forest and other classifiers achieved varying accuracies in cited work (example claims: random forest 83% accuracy in Khan et al.; random forest 64% in Gholamian & Davoodi; multiple classifiers combined achieved 65% in Qian & Rasheed)
Result: Many reviewed studies train algorithms on historical price data and additional attributes (news, macro variables, indicators) to forecast next-day or short-term stock direction or price
Claim: Accurate machine learning predictions can help investors decide when to buy at low prices and sell at high prices, reducing investment risk and increasing profit potential

Conclusion: Machine learning is a valuable tool for stock market prediction, but prediction difficulty remains due to market dynamics and event influences; model performance depends on choice of algorithm, input attributes, and data size

Limitation: Reviewed literature shows variable accuracy across methods and datasets, indicating no universally best model and the need for larger datasets, better attributes, and context-specific evaluation
